details.description: Types of public service vehicle (PSV) operator licences, application forms and application guidance notes. Appealing a decision and making changes to your licence

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
You need a public service vehicle (PSV) operator’s licence to:

  • operate a vehicle for hire or reward (payment or payment in kind) that can carry 9 or more passengers
  • operate a smaller vehicle carrying passengers and charging separate fares for the journey

Download ‘PSV437, PSV operator licensing – a guide for operators’ (PDF, 1.6MB)

Types of PSV licence

There are 4 types of PSV operator licences, plus special licensing rules in London.

Standard licence - national operations only

If you apply for a standard licence you can only operate within Great Britain. Most full-time commercial operators use standard licences.

Standard licence - national and international operations

This kind of licence lets you take passengers abroad as well as within Great Britain.

Restricted licence

You can only apply for a restricted licence for small-scale operations. They allow you to use 1 or 2 vehicles, and neither can carry more than 8 passengers.

You can carry up to 16 passengers in either vehicle if you don’t use it as part of a passenger transport business, or you’re operating your vehicles as a sideline and not as your main job.

Special restricted licence

Special restricted licences are used to operate a licensed taxi on a local service. You can only apply for this licence if you’re a licensed taxi operator. A local service is one where:

  • stops are no more than 24.15 kilometres (15 miles) apart
  • at least one stop is within the area of the district council that issued your taxi or private hire vehicle (PHV) licence.

The service must be registered with the local Traffic Commissioner.

Licensing in London

You’ll need a London Service Permit to run a private bus or coach service in London.

Taxis and private hire services in London are licensed by Transport for London (TfL).

parts.title: How to apply for a PSV licence
parts.body:
Standard and restricted licences

You can apply for a PSV licence using form PSV421. The address to send it to is on the form.

Download ‘PSV421, Application to a Traffic Commissioner for a Public Service Vehicle Operator’s Licence’ (PDF, 198KB)

You need to prove that you have the financial resources to maintain your vehicles properly.

Download ‘PSV421, Annex A, financial levels’ (PDF, 11KB)

You must sign an agreement with a garage or agent for safety inspections and repair of vehicles and trailers.

Download ‘PSV421, Annex C, maintenance contract’ (PDF, 16KB)

Guidance notes

There are detailed guidance notes on leaflet PSV421G to help you fill in your application correctly.

Download ‘PSV421G, Guidance notes to help you complete your application for a Public Service Vehicle Operator’s Licence’ (PDF, 175KB)

Special restricted licences for taxi and private hire vehicle operators

If you’re a licensed taxi (Hackney Carriage) or private hire vehicle operator you can apply for a special restricted PSV operator licence using form PSV356. The address to send it to is on the form.

Download ‘PSV356, Application to a Traffic Commissioner for a Special Restricted Public Service Vehicle Operator’s Licence’ (PDF, 48KB)

Guidance notes

There are detailed guidance notes on leaflet PSV356G to help you fill in your application correctly.

Download ‘PSV356G, Guidance notes to help you complete your application for a Special Restricted Public Service Vehicle Operator’s Licence’ (PDF, 21KB)

When to apply

Whatever the type of licence, you should apply at least 9 weeks before you need your licence.

It’s illegal to operate your vehicles before a licence has been issued.

Getting your licence

Once you’ve got your licence it won’t have an expiry date, but you’ll be asked to confirm your details every 5 years. The Traffic Commissioner’s Office will get in touch with you to check them. If you’ve got a special restricted (taxi) licence, you’ll need to pay a continuation fee.

The Traffic Commissioner can suspend or revoke your licence if they suspect you’ve been breaking its terms.

You must also tell the Traffic Commissioner if your circumstances change.

Fees

Type of licence Fees
Application for a standard licence £206
Application for a restricted licence £206
Variation of a licence £121
Application for a special restricted (taxi) licence £61
Continuation fee for a special restricted (taxi) licence (payable every 5 years) £61

Ways you can pay

You can pay for your licence online, by phone or by post.

Paying online

You can pay online by registering for the VOSA operator licensing self-service system.

Paying by phone

You can pay by phone by calling the VOSA helpline.

VOSA helpline
0300 123 9000

Paying by post

You can pay by cheque or postal order, made payable to ‘VOSA’. Send to VOSA Central Licensing Office.


VOSA Central Licensing Office
Hillcrest House
386 Harehills Lane
Leeds
LS9 6NF

parts.title: Making changes to your PSV licence
parts.body:
Minor variations

You can apply to make minor variations to your licence for free. These include:

  • adding vehicles to your licence
  • removing vehicles from your licence
  • adding or removing operating centres
  • adding or removing a transport manager (standard national and standard international licences only)

Download ‘PSV430, Vehicles to be used under a PSV operator’s licence’ (PDF, 42KB)

Download ‘PSV430G, Guidance notes to help you complete your application to change the vehicles used under your PSV operator’s licence’ (PDF, 26KB)

Download ‘PSV431AG, Guidance notes to help you complete your application to vary a PSV operator’s licence’ (PDF, 38KB)

How to make minor variations

You can apply to make minor variations to your PSV licence online if you register for the operator licensing self-service system.

You can also fill in PSV431A and send to the address on the form.

Download ‘PSV431A, Application to a Traffic Commissioner for a non-chargeable variation of a PSV operator’s licence’ (PDF, 65KB)

Download ‘PSV431G, Guidance on varying a PSV operators licence’ (PDF, 47KB)

You can also use this form to apply to upgrade from a standard national licence to a standard international licence if you don’t want to increase the number of vehicles you can operate.

Transport managers

You can apply to be a transport manager or add a transport manager to a licence.

Download ‘TM1, Application to add a transport manager to a licence’ (PDF, 49KB)

Download ‘TM1G, Guidance notes’ (PDF, 50KB)

Major variations

You’ll have to pay a fee if you want to:

  • increase the number of vehicles you’re authorised to operate
  • upgrade your licence from standard national to standard international and increase your vehicle authorisation at the same time

How to apply for major variations

You can apply to make major variations to your PSV licence online if you register for the operator licensing self-service system.

You can also fill in PSV431 and send to the address on the form.

Download ‘PSV431, Application to a Traffic Commissioner for a chargeable variation of a Public Service Vehicle Operator’s Licence’ (PDF, 141KB)

Download ‘PSV431G, Guidance on varying a PSV Operators Licence’ (PDF, 47KB)

Changes of circumstance

You must tell the Traffic Commissioner within 28 days if:

  • there’s any change to the correspondence address of the business
  • there’s any change to the establishment address (standard licences only)
  • there’s any change in the address of your operating centres
  • there’s any change in the trading name of the business
  • any of the persons named on the licence have died (in this case you may need a new licence)
  • there’s been a change of partners if it’s a partnership firm (in this case you may need a new licence)
  • there’s been a change of transport managers
  • you, your transport manager, officers employees or agents have any relevant convictions
  • there’s been any other change that the Traffic Commissioner asked you to report as a condition of getting your licence

You’ll also have to tell the Traffic Commissioner if there’s been a change in the ‘legal entity’ of your business, for example if:

  • your company changes from being a sole trader or partnership to a limited company
  • there’s been a change in your registered company number
  • there’s been a change of directors or change in share holding

Send details of any changes to the Office of the Traffic Commissioner’s Central Licensing Office.

Central Licensing Office
Hillcrest House
386 Harehills Lane
Leeds
LS9 6NF
0300 123 9000

Getting a duplicate licence

Download ‘PSV451, Duplicate PSV Disc Form’ (PDF, 20KB)

Giving up your licence

You can apply to give up (‘surrender’) your licence by completing form SUR1.

Download ‘SUR1, Application to surrender a goods or public service vehicle operator’s licence’ (PDF, 28KB)

parts.title: Appealing a decision
parts.body:
If your application for a PSV operator licence is refused you can appeal.

You’ll need to send a written notice of appeal to the Upper Tribunal, Administrative Appeals Chamber. There is no fee.

Your notice of appeal needs to be received within 1 month of the Traffic Commissioner’s decision.


Upper Tribunal
Administrative Appeals Chamber
Traffic Commissioner Appeals
7th Floor
Victory House
30-34 Kingsway
London
WC2B 6EX

Upper Tribunal
transport@tribunals.gsi.gov.uk
0202 3077 5850
Monday to Friday, 9am to 5pm

Guidance on making an appeal

You can download detailed Tribunals Service guidance on making an appeal.

Download ‘Appeals to the Administrative Appeals Chamber of the Upper Tribunal: Traffic Commissioner appeals’ (PDF, 163KB)

Appealing an Upper Tribunal decision

If your appeal is unsuccessful and you think that the decision is wrong, you can appeal to the Court of Appeal (England and Wales) or the Court of Session (Scotland).

You must have permission from the Upper Tribunal, or if the Upper Tribunal refuses, from the Court.

Your application for permission to appeal must be received within 1 month of the original appeal decision.

You can download detailed guidance about appealing an Upper Tribunal decision.

Download ‘Notes for Appellants Form UT12 (Traffic Commissioner appeals)’ (PDF, 31KB)
